wikipedia_page.main: Humphrey Hopper (1767–1844) was an English sculptor and stonemason. He was given the government commission for the memorial in St Paul's Cathedral to General Andrew Hay.

response: Simeon died, unmarried, on 13 November 1836, and was buried on 19 November in King's College Chapel, Cambridge. His memorial by Humphrey Hopper in Holy Trinity, Cambridge, was described by architectural critic Nikolaus Pevsner as an "epitaph in Gothic forms."Nikolaus Pevsner. Cambridgeshire. "The Buildings of England." Second Edition (London: Penguin Books, 1970), p.231.
The early 19th century sculptor Humphrey Hopper was born here.
*Humphrey Hopper (active 1830s), English, active in Cambridge, Cambridgeshire

Spry was knighted at Portsmouth on 24 June 1773 and retired to Place House in St Anthony in Roseland, Cornwall.Cornwall: Walking along the Roseland peninsula Daily Telegraph, 12 August 2000 He died there in 1775. His memorial in St Anthony's Church there is by Humphrey Hopper.

He died while the Reform Bill was still going through the House of Commons, on 29 September 1831 and is buried in St Mary's Church, Harrow-on-the-Hill where a memorial (attributed to Humphrey Hopper) bears the inscription:

St Martin of Tours church, Epsom
response: |Edward Knipe (1825) and his wife Caroline (Western) Knipe      ||Humphrey Hopper

Works of art in the town hall include two portraits by Nicaise de Keyser of a Syrian Chief, a landscape painting by John Charles Dollman depicting Ditchling Beacon and a painting by T. Hardy depicting the Battle of Lewes. There is also a portrait by Cave Thomas of the first mayor of Lewes, Wynne Edwin Baxter, and a bust by Humphrey Hopper depicting Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington.
